title: How to Clean, Disinfect, and Care for Your Touch Screen

steps.title: Turn off your device and unplug any accessories first.
steps.content: Turn off your device and unplug any accessories first. Before you clean your screen, it’s best to power down your device completely and unplug any cables, dongles, or other accessories. This will reduce the risk of shocks or damage to your device, especially if you plan to use any liquid cleaners.

steps.title: Wipe your screen with a dry microfiber cloth.
steps.content: Wipe your screen with a dry microfiber cloth. A dry, lint-free microfiber cloth is all you need for most simple screen cleaning jobs. You can use the kind of cleaning cloth you’d use to clean a pair of glasses, or get one specially made for screens or electronics . Apply light pressure and use small, circular movements to wipe away dust and smudges.

steps.title: Dampen the cloth lightly with water for stubborn gunk.
steps.content: Dampen the cloth lightly with water for stubborn gunk. If a dry cloth isn’t doing the trick, you can dampen the cloth. Just be sure to squeeze out any excess moisture. Your cloth should be slightly damp, not wet. Gently wipe any problem areas with the damp cloth, then wipe your screen dry with a dry part of the cloth or let it air dry. You can also add a couple drops of mild soap, such as liquid dish soap, if necessary. steps.title: Try specialized screen wipes or sprays.
steps.content: Try specialized screen wipes or sprays. If your screen is extra grimy or you like the convenience of a ready-made cleaning wipe or spray, there are lots of products on the market that are designed to be safe for touchscreens. According to computer repair specialist Joseph Alexander, pre-moistened lens wipes, like the kind you’d use for glasses, are generally safe for touch screens as well. [2] X Expert Source Mobile Kangaroo Computer & Phone Repair Specialists Expert Interview. 11 September 2019. You can also get cleaning wipes that are made just for screens and electronics . If you use a screen cleaning spray, apply the spray to a microfiber cleaning cloth and not directly to your screen. Many of these sprays come in a kit with a cleaning cloth .

steps.title: Power down and unplug your device before you start.
steps.content: Power down and unplug your device before you start. Disinfecting your screen is different from just cleaning it. If you’re concerned about killing bacteria and viruses, and not just getting rid of smudges and dust, disinfecting is the way to go. Before you begin, turn your device off completely and unplug any cords or accessories.

steps.title: Wipe your screen with a screen-safe disinfecting wipe.
steps.content: Wipe your screen with a screen-safe disinfecting wipe. Some wipes that are safe for most delicate touch screens include 70% isopropyl alcohol wipes, 75% ethyl alcohol wipes, and Clorox Disinfecting Wipes. [3] X Research source Be careful not to get liquid from the wipe into any openings on your device. You can also buy disinfecting wipes that are made just for screens, such as Weiman Electronic & Screen Disinfecting Wipes or Wipex 70% Isopropyl Alcohol Wipes for Electronics.

steps.title: Make a mild disinfecting solution if you don’t have wipes.
steps.content: Make a mild disinfecting solution if you don’t have wipes. You can use rubbing alcohol and distilled water to make a disinfecting spray for your touch screen in a pinch. Mix equal parts 70% isopropyl alcohol and distilled water in a spray bottle. Shake the bottle to mix the ingredients, then mist the solution onto a lint-free cleaning cloth and wipe you’re your screen. [4] X Research source Avoid using pure alcohol on your screen, since it could eventually damage the screen’s delicate surface.

steps.title: Don’t use too much liquid.
steps.content: Don’t use too much liquid. Even if your touch screen device is water resistant, liquids and electronics don’t mix. Never soak your tablet, phone, or other touch screen device in a cleaning solution, and don’t spray liquids directly on the screen. [5] X Trustworthy Source Federal Communications Commission Independent U.S. government agency responsible for regulating radio, television, and satellite, and phone communications Go to source If you’re using a damp cloth, squeeze out excess liquid first. Be extra careful when cleaning around speakers, ports, and other openings.

steps.title: Avoid harsh cleansers.
steps.content: Avoid harsh cleansers. Cleansers that contain bleach, ammonia, hydrogen peroxide, or high concentrations of alcohol (above 70% isopropyl alcohol or 75% ethyl alcohol) can damage your screen. For cleaning, stick to gentle cleansers like plain water or mild soap. If you have to disinfect your phone, always use screen-safe disinfectant wipes.

steps.title: Be careful not to apply too much pressure.
steps.content: Be careful not to apply too much pressure. Pushing too hard on your phone when you’re wiping it can crack the screen. Always wipe gently, and use a mild cleanser if you need a bit of extra cleaning power.

steps.title: Steer clear of abrasive cleaning cloths.
steps.content: Steer clear of abrasive cleaning cloths. Always use a soft, microfiber cloth or a pre-moistened lens or electronics wipe to clean your touch screen. Never use scrubby or abrasive cloths or sponges. Paper towels can also scratch up the surface of your touch screen.
